x10.mongo.yak
Class YakCursor

x10.lang.Object
  x10.mongo.yak.YakCursor
All Implemented Interfaces:
x10.lang.Any
public class YakCursor
extends x10.lang.Object
implements x10.lang.Iterable<YakMap>

Yak implementation of cursors. It is little more than a Yak-ified wrapper around the Java class com.mongodb.DBCursor, so that it can return YakMaps rather than the less X10-styled DBObjects.

Like the underlying Java class com.mongodb.DBCursor, a cursor is either a reference to some database results (which is cheap), or an array of results (which can be very large if there are a lot of results). Calling length or toArray will convert the result set into an array. Don't do this until you have narrowed the results to just the ones you want in the array.

Method Detail

hashCode

public x10.lang.Int hashCode()
An ordinary hash code method.

equals

public x10.lang.Boolean equals(x10.lang.Any a)
An ordinary equality test.

Parameters:
a -

explain

public YakMap explain()
Returns an object containing some information about the execution of the query that created this cursor. This creates a YakMap containing:
  1. "cursor": cursor type
  2. "millis": how long it took the database to execute this query, in millisecond.
  3. "n": number of records that the database returned for this cursor.
  4. "nScanned": number of records that this query caused the database to examine

snapshot

public YakCursor snapshot()
This does the same thing as com.mongodb.DBCursor.snapshot(). As that method's javadoc says:
Snapshot mode assures no duplicates are returned, or objects missed, which were present at both the start and end of the query's execution (if an object is new during the query, or deleted during the query, it may or may not be returned, even with snapshot mode). Note that short query responses (less than 1MB) are always effectively snapshotted. Currently, snapshot mode may not be used with sorting or explicit hints.

copy

public YakCursor copy()
Create a copy of a YakCursor. The copy is always a cursor, even if the original is backed by an array.

sort

public YakCursor sort(com.mongodb.DBObject sorting)
Sort the values that the cursor will yield, by sort criterion sorting. This must be called before any values are obtained from the cursor. This is called purely for side effects, and returns this.

Parameters:
sorting -

addSpecial

public YakCursor addSpecial(x10.lang.String specialName,
                            x10.lang.Any value)
Add a meta query operator to this. For example, this.addSpecial("$maxScan", 100) or this.addSpecial("$returnKey", 1). See the Mongo spec for what the meta query operators are. Some of them can be invoked in other ways; e.g., $orderBy is equivalent to a call to sort().

Parameters:
specialName - Name of the meta query operator
value - Its value
See Also:
http://www.mongodb.org/display/DOCS/Advanced+Queries

hint

public YakCursor hint(com.mongodb.DBObject hint)
Force the database to use a particular index for this query. If used well, this can improve performance. Be sure to call hint() before accessing any data.

Parameters:
hint - A BSON object whose fields are the keys in the index.
See Also:
http://www.mongodb.org/display/DOCS/Optimization#Optimization-Hint

hint

public YakCursor hint(x10.lang.String indexName)
Force the database to use a particular index for this query. If used well, this can improve performance. Be sure to call hint() before accessing any data.

Parameters:
indexName - Name of the index to use.
See Also:
http://www.mongodb.org/display/DOCS/Optimization#Optimization-Hint

batchSize

public YakCursor batchSize(x10.lang.Int size)
Set the maximum number of documents that this cursor will return from server to client in a batch; you generally will not care about this, since Mongo presents results to you as if they came in a single batch.

Parameters:
size -
See Also:
http://www.mongodb.org/display/DOCS/Advanced+Queries#AdvancedQueries-%7B%7BbatchSize%28%29%7D%7D

skip

public YakCursor skip(x10.lang.Int nIgnored)
Make the iteration start somewhere other than with the first element; this can be expensive. Read the Mongo documentation about this if you are doing anything nontrivial with it.

Parameters:
nIgnored -
See Also:
http://www.mongodb.org/display/DOCS/Advanced+Queries#AdvancedQueries-%7B%7Bskip%28%29%7D%7D

getCursorId

public x10.lang.Long getCursorId()
Return the ID of the cursor, or 0 if there no active cursor. This just calls the Java method.

close

public void close()
Kills the current cursor on the server.

slaveOk

public YakCursor slaveOk()
Deprecated; use ReadPreference.SECONDARY. Makes this query runnable on a secondary server. Returns this for chaining.

addOption

public YakCursor addOption(x10.lang.Int option)
Add a query option to the underlying query. See the static fields of com.mongodb.Bytes whose names start with QUERYOPTION_ for the options.

Parameters:
option - Option to add.

Return the number of times that the cursor has retrieved batches of results from the database.

public x10.lang.Boolean hasNext()
Returns true if there are one or more objects to return.

next

public YakMap next()
Returns the next object from the iteration, if there is one, or throws an exception if not.

curr

public com.mongodb.DBObject curr()
Re-returns the current object.

remove

public void remove()
Not implemented. This method is required for the Java iteration framework, but it is inappropriate for cursors.

length

public x10.lang.Int length()
Converts the cursor into an in-memory array and returns the size of that array. This can be very expensive if all you want is the length.

toArray

public java.util.List toArray()
Converts the cursor into an in-memory array. For efficiency, this returns a java.util.List. If you want a list of X10 objects, use toX10List.

toX10List

public x10.util.List<YakMap> toX10List()
Converts the cursor to an in-memory list of YakMaps. Warning: this is implemented inefficiently, first converting the cursor to a Java array and then converting that into an X10 list. The former conversion is cached by the underlying Java object, so there is a point to having both.

toArray

public java.util.List toArray(x10.lang.Int max)
Convert the cursor to an in-memory array with a limit on how many elements to include.

Parameters:
max - Maximum number of elements to include.

count

public x10.lang.Int count()
Count the elements in the underlying query, ignoring limit and skip. Evidently an alias for size().

size

public x10.lang.Int size()
Count the elements in the underlying query, ignoring limit and skip. Evidently an alias for count().

getKeysWanted

public YakMap getKeysWanted()
Return a BSON object whose field names are the names of the fields this query will return, or null if all keys are returned.

getQuery

public YakMap getQuery()
Return the query that this cursor is iterating over.

getCollection

public YakCollection getCollection()
Return the collection that this cursor is iterating over.

getServerAddress

public com.mongodb.ServerAddress getServerAddress()
Return the server address, if known. This is certain to fail if no data has been retrieved yet. It may also fail under other circumstances, depending on the underlying implementation.

public YakCursor setReadPreference(com.mongodb.ReadPreference prefs)
Set the read preferences.

Parameters:
prefs -

Return the current read preferences.

Parameters:

Return the decoder factory.

Standard string conversion.

public x10.lang.Iterator<YakMap> iterator()
X10-style iteration over the cursor, returning values as YakMaps.

anyIterator

public x10.lang.Iterator<x10.lang.Any> anyIterator()
X10-style iteration over the cursor, but returning the underlying values as seen by Java -- probably DBObjects rather than YakMaps.

Yak implementation of cursors.  It is little more than a Yak-ified
wrapper around the Java class com.mongodb.DBCursor, so that
it can return YakMaps rather than the less X10-styled DBObjects.


Like the underlying Java class com.mongodb.DBCursor, a cursor is either
a reference to some database results (which is cheap), or an array of results (which can be
very large if there are a lot of results).  Calling length or toArray will
convert the result set into an array.  Don't do this until you have narrowed the results to
just the ones you want in the array.
